body.p: A political polling agency wants to take a random sample of registered voters and ask whether or not they will vote for a certain candidate. One plan is to select 400 voters, another plan is to select 1,600 voters.
If the study were conducted repeatedly (selecting different samples of people each time), which one of the following would be true regarding the resulting sample proportions of "yes" responses?

input.choice: Different sample proportions would result each time, but for either sample size, they would be centered (have their mean) at the true population proportion.
Different sample proportions would result each time, but for sample size 1,600 they would be centered (have their mean) at the true population proportion, whereas for sample size 400 they would not.
Different sample proportions would result each time, but for sample size 400 they would be centered (have their mean) at the true population proportion, whereas for sample size 1,600 they would not.
For either sample size, using the same size each time, as long as the samples are drawn with replacement, they would be centered (have a mean) at 0.

response.feedback: Correct. Due to sampling variability, for different samples we will get different values of p̂. Since the mean of the sampling distribution of p̂ is p, the population proportion, whether we take a sample of size 400 or a sample of size 1,600, the resulting values of p̂ will be centered around p in both cases.
Incorrect. Remember that the sampling distribution of p̂ will be normally distributed with a mean of p, the population proportion.
Incorrect. Remember that the sampling distribution of p̂ will be normally distributed with a mean of p, the population proportion.

Incorrect. Remember that the sampling distribution of p̂ will be normally distributed with mean p, the population proportion. Because the sampling distribution is normally distributed, and p̂ cannot take on negative values, it doesn’t make sense to have the sampling distribution centered at 0.

Different sample proportions would result each time, but for sample size 100 they would be centered (have their mean) at the true population proportion, whereas for sample size 900 they would not.

For either sample size, using the same size each time, as long as the sampling is done with replacement, their mean would be 0.
